Letter B-23-37
Morgan.
10/19
As against the advantages of this program there is nothing to look
forward to other than a very dubious claim against a reluctant and contentiaus
creditor, the Chinese Government, when the war is over.
The recent statements of President Roosevelt and
the State Department
have created a very favorable sentiment towards the United States.
Also the
Chinese Aviation Comnission which was so arrogant and
self
sufficient has made
a miserable failure and proven conclusively
that the
Chinese Air
Force without
American or other foreign assistance is a hopeless failure.
In CNAC this same
situation has developed and our Chinese associates realize that unless American
supervision of mechanical work and flight routine is reestablished that CNAC
will have nothing
left in another thirty days.
It is clear
that the opinions
of men like T. V.
Soong who have always maintained that the Chinese are not yet
ready to take over their own aviation activities,
are now prevailing and there
is an insistent demand on the Ministry that negotiations be undertaken
the return of American cooperation and technical assistance.
т.
V.
to assure
Soong knows
for instance that we were forced out by a series of high handed
and
silly
orders
issued by the Ministry of Communications and there is no doubt in my mind but
that he and men like him have had a showdown and have issued an ultimatum to
Lum Wei-shing and the Ministry demanding that such steps be taken as necessary
within reason to bring us back into the
picture.
In our conference at Hongkong
on October 6th Mr. Bond
said that the Managing Director talked of nothing else but

I em perfectly willing to go to Nanking provided you give me
ority to make the best deal I

Very truly yours,
PAN AMERICAN AIRWAYS COMPANY
